Changes to Improve Safety:
Upton Assets, LLC is committed to operating the Pecos Liquids Handling Facility in a safe manner for employees, the public and the environment.  The Pecos facility will conduct compliance audits and hazard reviews as required and will make improvements to safety based on the findings from the audits and reviews.

Management of Change:
The Pecos Liquids Handling Facility has written procedures in place to manage and document changes to all covered processes.  To control and manage facility changes, a systematic approach is followed to minimize the possibility that such changes will have an adverse impact on personnel safety, equipment or the environment.  Any employees, process operators or maintenance personnel whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Incident Investigation:
Upton Assets, LLC promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.   The investigation is led by an incident investigation team consisting of those with appropriate knowledge and experience in the process.  These investigations are completed to identify the situation leading to the incident, as well as corrective actions that could prevent the release from reoccurring.  The findings of the investigation are documented and the results are reviewed by all employees who have the potential to be affected by the findings.

Emergency Planning and Response:
The Pecos facility keeps a written emergency response plan onsite which includes the designated actions the company and all employees will take to ensure personal safety from fire and other emergencies.   The plan outlines actions that employees are to take when there is a release and facilitates the prompt evacuation of employees when necessary.

Compliance Audits:
The Pecos facility will conduct audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being properly implemented. The audit team will include individuals knowledgeable

maintains written procedures that identify various modes of process operation, such as initial startup, normal/temporary operations, emergency/normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown.  Operating procedures are frequently reviewed and certified as current.  When a process change occurs, operating procedures are revised as necessary.

Training:
Upton Assets, LLC has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees are competent in the operating procedures associated with the facility.

Hot Work Permit:
The Pecos HG Liquids Handling Facility issues hot work permits for all how work operations and provided all employees with hot work permit training.

Contractors:
On occasion, contractors are hired to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. The Pecos facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors are trained in the work practices of the facility, follow the safety rules of the facility, advise the facility employees of any unique hazards presented by the contractor and notify the facility of all illnesses and injuries that occur in process areas.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs):
The Pecos facility conducts a PSSR for facility modifications that require a change in the process safety information.  The PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  A standard checklist is used to document compliance.

Mechanical Integrity:
Highly documented maintenance checks on all equipment are completed at the Pecos facility to ensure proper operations.  Equipment examples include pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, pumps, valves and temperature and pressure switches. in 40 CFR 68.42.

Local Emergency Response Coordination:
The Pecos Liquids Handling Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with the local fire department.  Also, operators of the facility are equipped with a written emergency response plan.  This plan includes information regarding adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public and decontamination of the affected area after the incident has occurred.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Pecos Liquids Handling Facility has processes that are subject to EPA's RMP regulations and the OSHA's PSM standards; therefore, this summary addresses each of the required elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation:
All level of employees and contract employees are encouraged to participate in making a safe work environment.  Employees are asked to provide opinions concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.   Employees are expected to maintain rule compliance based on their knowledge, experience and job responsibilities.

Process Safety Information:
The Pecos Liquids Handling Facility maintains a detailed record of information for identifying and understanding the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the facility processes.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):
Upton Assets, LLC conducts comprehensive studies to help ensure that hazards associated with various processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  These studies are completed by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations.  To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviated from the original designed safety features, the handling facility updates and revalidates the hazard analysis at least every five years.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Upton Assets, LLC owns and operates the Pecos Liquids Handling Facility, a natural gas liquids processing plant, located approximately 5.75 miles west of Pecos, Texas.  The incoming Natural Gas Liquids and condensate streams are stabilized and treated to meet sales specifications and routed to pressurized tanks for storage.  Based on criteria outlined in the Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Program, the Pecos Liquids Handling Facility is subject to the requirements of OSHA’s Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard codified under 29 CFR 1910.119.  Further, the facility is subject to US EPA’s Risk Management Program Level 2. 

Storage of Hazardous Material and Potential Exposure:
The regulated flammable substances identified at the facility are NGLs and un-stabilized condensate. For the purpose of identifying the maximum release quantity for use in determining potential off-site impacts, it is assumed that the entire contents of the vessel or the system are released to the atmosphere, presenting a worst-case scenario (WCS) of release through vapor cloud explosion.  NGL (Off Spec) stored in TK-103 (Off Spec NGL Storage Tank) with a level of 54,000 gallons was determined to result in the WCS.  The distance to the endpoint of 1-psi overpressure for the worst-case release of the flammable mixture was calculated to be 0.50 mile using the EPA’s RMP*Comp.  An alternative scenario of release type of BLEVE was used to calculate an endpoint distance of 0.6 miles at which exposure may cause second-degree burns.  Within 0.6 miles of the facility, approximately 50 mobile homes are parked in the man-camp setting that are considered to be receptors potentially impacted by exposure through the wort-case and alternative scenarios.
